nexttext: Here, $b(b^\dag)$ is the annihilation(creation) bosonic operator and $\sigma^{x,z}$ are Pauli matrices. We denote $\omega_{\rm cav}$ as the cavity mode frequency, $\omega_p$ and $g_p$ as the qubit gap frequency and the qubit-cavity coupling strength, respectively. In addition, two qubits with gap frequencies $\omega_{q1}$ and $\omega_{q2}$ are coupled to the polariton via the cavity mode with coupling strengths $g_1$ and $g_2$, respectively. In this situation, the Hamiltonian for our model reads

prevtext: Here, $b(b^\dag)$ is the annihilation(creation) bosonic operator and $\sigma^{x,z}$ are Pauli matrices. We denote $\omega_{\rm cav}$ as the cavity mode frequency, $\omega_p$ and $g_p$ as the qubit gap frequency and the qubit-cavity coupling strength, respectively. In addition, two qubits with gap frequencies $\omega_{q1}$ and $\omega_{q2}$ are coupled to the polariton via the cavity mode with coupling strengths $g_1$ and $g_2$, respectively. In this situation, the Hamiltonian for our model reads

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle H=H_{p}+\sum_{n=1,2}\frac{\hbar\omega_{qn}}{2}\sigma^{z}_{n}+%
\hbar g_{n}\sigma^{x}_{n}(b+b^{\dagger})." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>p</mi></msub><mo>+</mo><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mrow><mi>n</mi><mo>=</mo><mrow><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn></mrow></mrow></munder></mstyle><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ω</mi><mrow><mi>q</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow><mn>2</mn></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>σ</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>z</mi></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">ℏ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>g</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>σ</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>x</mi></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mi>b</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>b</mi><mo>†</mo></msup></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{\rm eff}=H_{p}+\sum_{n=1,2}\frac{\hbar\omega_{qn}}{2}\sigma^{z}_{n}+\frac{%

nexttext: We proceed by defining the time average of an operator $\mathcal{O}(t)$ \cite{Omar2010} as
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E5.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="i\frac{\partial}{\partial t}U(t,t_{0})=\tilde{H}_{I}(t)U(t,t_{0})." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mfrac><mo>∂</mo><mrow><mo>∂</mo><mo>⁡</mo><mi>t</mi></mrow></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>I</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mi>U</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>0</mn></msub><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $f(t)$ is real and has unit area. There are two important timescales that play important roles in our system dynamics, namely the contributions from the polariton eigenfrequency and from the two qubits frequencies. At present, we are interested in the dispersive limit where the two qubits frequencies are far off-resonant with the polariton eigenfrequency. In this particular scenario, fast oscillatory dynamics can be averaged out and thus only slow dynamics contribute to the overall system dynamics. Therefore, Eq.~(\ref{SEqn}) can be taken as

nexttext: Here, $\mathcal{T}$ represents usual time-ordered operator. Up to the first order Taylor expansion, $U(t,t_0)= 1+ U_1 (t)$, where $U_1(t) = -i \int_{t_0} ^t dt' \tilde{H}_I (t')$. In this way, Eq.~(\ref{Heff2}) is transformed into

prevtext: Here, $\mathcal{T}$ represents usual time-ordered operator. Up to the first order Taylor expansion, $U(t,t_0)= 1+ U_1 (t)$, where $U_1(t) = -i \int_{t_0} ^t dt' \tilde{H}_I (t')$. In this way, Eq.~(\ref{Heff2}) is transformed into
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E10.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="H_{\text{eff}}(t)=\overline{\tilde{H}_{I}(t)}+\frac{1}{2}\left(\overline{[%

\right)." display="block"><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>H</mi><mtext>eff</mtext></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>I</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>+</mo><mrow><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo>(</mo><mrow><mover accent="true"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>I</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>-</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>H</mi><mo stretchy="false">~</mo></mover><mi>I</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo>,</mo><mover accent="true"><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>¯</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext: where $S_n$ are Hermitian system operators, and operators $U_n$ are defined as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E11.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\dot{\rho}=-i[H_{s},\rho]+\sum_{n}(U_{n}\rho S_{n}+S_{n}\rho U^{{\dagger}}_{n}%
-S_{n}U_{n}\rho-\rho U^{{\dagger}}_{n}S_{n})," display="block"><mrow><mrow><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo>=</mo><mrow><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>,</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><munder><mo largeop="true" movablelimits="false" symmetric="true">∑</mo><mi>n</mi></munder><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup></mrow></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ρ</mi></mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>ρ</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msubsup><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>†</mo></msubsup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Here, one considers independent thermal baths for each loss mechanism acting on the system described by the Hamiltonian $H_s$, which is Eq. (\ref{HTotal}) of the main text. In our simulation, we have taken into account operators $S_{x_1}=\sigma^x_1$ for the incoherent pumping acting on qubit $1$ ($\gamma_{\rm pump}$), and $S_{x_2}=\sigma^x_2$ for the spontaneous emission of qubit $2$ ($\gamma_{\rm out}$). Moreover, we include loss mechanisms acting on the polariton via transversal noise ($\gamma_x$), longitudinal noise ($\gamma_z$), and noise acting on the field quadrature ($\gamma_{\rm cav}$), through operators $S_{x_3}=\sigma^x_3$, $S_{z_3}=\sigma^z_3$, and $S_{q}=b + b^{\dag}$, respectively. In our treatment, each loss/pump mechanism is described by independent thermal baths with bare loss/pump rates $\gamma_j$. This leads to $\gamma_j(\omega)=(\gamma_j/\omega_j)\omega$. Moreover, we consider zero-temperature thermal baths for each loss mechanism, except for the incoherent pumping on the qubit $1$, where we have defined an effective bare pump rate $\gamma_{\rm pump}=\gamma_{\rm pump}^0\bar{N}(\omega)$ such that $\gamma_{\rm pump}(\omega)=(\gamma_{\rm pump}/\omega_1)\omega$.  

The steady state solution of the density matrix can be found by means of the superspace method described in Ref.~\cite{Navarrete2015}. If the system of interest belongs to a Hilbert space of dimension ${\rm dim}({\mathcal{H}})=d$, the master equation in superspace reads
prevtext: where $S_n$ are Hermitian system operators, and operators $U_n$ are defined as
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle U_{n}(t)=" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>t</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\int_{0}^{\infty}d\tau~{}\nu_{n}(\tau)e^{-iH_{s}\tau}S_{n}e^{iH_{%
s}\tau}" display="inline"><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mn>0</mn><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mi>τ</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mrow></msup><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\nu_{n}(\tau)=" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>ν</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>τ</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E12.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}d\omega~{}\frac{\gamma_{n}(\omega)}{2\pi}[%
\bar{N}_{n}(\omega)e^{i\omega\tau}+(\bar{N}_{n}(\omega)+1)e^{-i\omega\tau}]." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msubsup><mo largeop="true" symmetric="true">∫</mo><mrow><mo>-</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">∞</mi></msubsup></mstyle><mrow><mrow><mo>𝑑</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mi>ω</mi></mpadded></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>γ</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn><mo>⁢</mo><mi>π</mi></mrow></mfrac></mstyle><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></msup></mrow><mo>+</mo><mrow><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mrow><mrow><msub><mover accent="true"><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">¯</mo></mover><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></mrow><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow><mo>⁢</mo><msup><mi>e</mi><mrow><mo>-</mo><mrow><mi>i</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>ω</mi><mo>⁢</mo><mi>τ</mi></mrow></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow></mrow></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>

nexttext:
Notice that the superspace dimension is ${\rm dim}(\mathcal{S})=d^2$. In the master equation, $\mathbb{I}$ is the superspace identity and we take into account the transpose and conjugate of system operators. The steady state solution is found under the condition ${\vert {\dot{\rho}} \rangle}=0$. This implies to find the eigenstate of $\mathcal{L}=-i~H_s\otimes \mathbb{I}+i~\mathbb{I}\otimes H_s^{T}
+ U_n\otimes S^{T}_n+S_n\otimes {U^{*}_n}-S_nU_n\otimes \mathbb{I}-\mathbb{I}\otimes A^{T}_nU^{*}_n$, with zero eigenvalue, that is
prevtext:
Here, one considers independent thermal baths for each loss mechanism acting on the system described by the Hamiltonian $H_s$, which is Eq. (\ref{HTotal}) of the main text. In our simulation, we have taken into account operators $S_{x_1}=\sigma^x_1$ for the incoherent pumping acting on qubit $1$ ($\gamma_{\rm pump}$), and $S_{x_2}=\sigma^x_2$ for the spontaneous emission of qubit $2$ ($\gamma_{\rm out}$). Moreover, we include loss mechanisms acting on the polariton via transversal noise ($\gamma_x$), longitudinal noise ($\gamma_z$), and noise acting on the field quadrature ($\gamma_{\rm cav}$), through operators $S_{x_3}=\sigma^x_3$, $S_{z_3}=\sigma^z_3$, and $S_{q}=b + b^{\dag}$, respectively. In our treatment, each loss/pump mechanism is described by independent thermal baths with bare loss/pump rates $\gamma_j$. This leads to $\gamma_j(\omega)=(\gamma_j/\omega_j)\omega$. Moreover, we consider zero-temperature thermal baths for each loss mechanism, except for the incoherent pumping on the qubit $1$, where we have defined an effective bare pump rate $\gamma_{\rm pump}=\gamma_{\rm pump}^0\bar{N}(\omega)$ such that $\gamma_{\rm pump}(\omega)=(\gamma_{\rm pump}/\omega_1)\omega$.  

The steady state solution of the density matrix can be found by means of the superspace method described in Ref.~\cite{Navarrete2015}. If the system of interest belongs to a Hilbert space of dimension ${\rm dim}({\mathcal{H}})=d$, the master equation in superspace reads

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle{|{\dot{\rho}}\rangle}=" display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mover accent="true"><mi>ρ</mi><mo>˙</mo></mover><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mi/></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex2.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle[-i~{}H_{s}\otimes\mathbb{I}+i~{}\mathbb{I}\otimes H_{s}^{T}" display="inline"><mrow><mo stretchy="false">[</mo><mo>-</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mi>i</mi></mpadded><msub><mi>H</mi><mi>s</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><mi>𝕀</mi><mo>+</mo><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mi>i</mi></mpadded><mi>𝕀</mi><mo>⊗</mo><msubsup><mi>H</mi><mi>s</mi><mi>T</mi></msubsup></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle+" display="inline"><mo>+</mo></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E13.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle U_{n}\otimes S^{T}_{n}+S_{n}\otimes{U^{*}_{n}}-S_{n}U_{n}\otimes%
\mathbb{I}-\mathbb{I}\otimes A^{T}_{n}U^{*}_{n}]{|{\rho}\rangle}," display="inline"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><msubsup><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>T</mi></msubsup><mo>+</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><msubsup><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>*</mo></msubsup><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>S</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><msub><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi></msub><mo>⊗</mo><mi>𝕀</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>𝕀</mi><mo>⊗</mo><msubsup><mi>A</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>T</mi></msubsup><msubsup><mi>U</mi><mi>n</mi><mo>*</mo></msubsup><mo stretchy="false">]</mo></mrow><mo stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo><mo>,</mo></mrow></math>

prevtext:
Notice that the superspace dimension is ${\rm dim}(\mathcal{S})=d^2$. In the master equation, $\mathbb{I}$ is the superspace identity and we take into account the transpose and conjugate of system operators. The steady state solution is found under the condition ${\vert {\dot{\rho}} \rangle}=0$. This implies to find the eigenstate of $\mathcal{L}=-i~H_s\otimes \mathbb{I}+i~\mathbb{I}\otimes H_s^{T}
+ U_n\otimes S^{T}_n+S_n\otimes {U^{*}_n}-S_nU_n\otimes \mathbb{I}-\mathbb{I}\otimes A^{T}_nU^{*}_n$, with zero eigenvalue, that is
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E14.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\displaystyle\mathcal{L}~{}{|{\rho}\rangle}_{\rm ss}=0." display="inline"><mrow><mrow><mrow><mpadded width="+3.3pt"><mi class="ltx_font_mathcaligraphic">ℒ</mi></mpadded><mo>⁢</mo><msub><mrow><mo fence="true" stretchy="false">|</mo><mi>ρ</mi><mo stretchy="false">⟩</mo></mrow><mi>ss</mi></msub></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></mrow><mo>.</mo></mrow></math>
